column3: Love how he reference "Hard working MEN" those are the ones that made Leadville what it is today..HARD WORK and no BS if you know what I mean....I do this race every year and permanently marked my body with Ink to signify what it means to me and the History behind it.....Make no mistake...behind every great hard working MAN, is the rock aka WIFE....

It's a great atmosphere. I did this several times back in the 90s before it got trendy. Did the Vail Ultra 100 too when it started up a rivalry with Leadville. They'd be one week after the other. Vail is too polished for me. Didn't like staying there.I lived in California at the time, so trained a lot at high altitude in the Sierras, so I would arrive acclimatized, so it wasn't too bad. I did the race in 2000 after living in the UK for a while, and suffered badly. Had to visit the medical tent afterwards and breathe oxygen. And for the rest of the week, couldn't sleep properly because of being unable to catch a full breath.They are right about "The Powerline". It's not a road. It's just where power pylons go STRAIGHT up the mountain, so it's a 20% gradient dirt trail.The trail up to Columbine mine is not too bad for most of its length. Above the tree line it's only semi rideable upwards.

Arguably one of the most noteworthy performances here is hardly featured at all since the rider, Quinn Simmons  (finishing  @20:05),  was not one of the "chosen‚Äù few for this video.  In fact he isn‚Äôt even mentioned by name despite finishing on the podium. Full story here: https://durangoherald.com/articles/289241 Short version: He rode with the leaders, lost contact (and much time) due to punctures from tacks on the course, chased back riding solo to take the sprint for second. An epic effort and result. And he was a junior! He also had another pretty good result on the road the following month: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hRAWul6Nd4IFun fact- the last American to win the junior world road championships was a fellow named Greg LeMond.

I have some advice for Leadville100 in 2020...........Have the downtown area roped off at the corner turn & supervised by police to keep lots of  cheaters from cutting in at the last minute after the start.  I personally watch this happen in 2019.  Not fair to cyclist who are in their correct corrals early before the start.  It matters when seconds count at the 40 mile marker before your sweepers disappoint riders who trained hard to get to that important marker by 10:30.  My son completed all his pre-course races in alotted time, so he could be disappointed at 40 mile marker by less than 1 minute during Leadville100. (His computer chip time was under 10:30) , yet his number was pulled.  There are TOO many riders bunched up trying to get into a rhythm the first 20 miles, which slows all cyclists down.   CHEATERS should be stopped.  Lots of money and time is invested in this race & I expect a professional race committee to oversee it.  You call yourself one of the best,  I say demonstrate it , instead of just talking about it.  YOU need to DIG DEEP and show all riders you really care.  MAJOR  MONEY is fed into your economy during the race series.  SIGNED by a MOM & 9th year CENTURY RIDER FROM TEXAS where temps are 108-113 at finish line.

It's a cool race in and of itself but most of the people who come here for it ablsoluley trash the town and treat the locals like shit. Not a fan. Leadville sees none of the money either. They boast about jobs, this is a very short event, theres less than 15 Lead role race series year round employees...
Leadville is doing much better now! Tourism has helped so much, the mine re-opened in 2012, too.

To be introduced in Belgian Ardennes and Hautes Fagnes. Interesting concept. Imagine passing those small Battle of the Bulge towns and people cheering.....  What I would do in Leadville is to let riders start in packs in order to avoid standstills. It will give a more dynamic dimension to the race.

Why 1x SUX - ""as soon as I was running I realized I was going faster..."" That is NOT how gearing is supposed to work. Gearing makes you faster in every riding situation than walking/running. 1X BLOWS. So happy to not have it.

"I've pushed through enough injuries in my career..." Taylor Phinney. Jeez, such an understatement. A few feet either way, and maybe Taylor died hitting that guardrail. If the guy never wins, never even podiums again, just to come back and be racing at such a high level after that crash is truly amazing. Guys in Lycra might not seem as tough as contact sports dudes, but the  more you know about bike racing, the more you realize how hard as nails these folks are, going through what they do.Somebody sign him up for 2020 already! I want to see him in Paris-Roubaix again!

Thanks Rapha and EF for putting forward another perspective, and I must admit, an excellent backing track. Thanks to the riders for sharing their thoughts and reactions. Real, earthy, muddy, and inspiring.
